ygData.subject: Re: Symmetry, concepts and data buses in the brain
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Ian: Apologizes for my English, I meant Differentiable Programs . It means that a recurrent ANN with LSTM cells is able to create Loops, counters,

Hi Ian:

Apologizes for my English, I meant "Differentiable Programs". It =
means
that a "recurrent ANN" with LSTM cells is able to create Loops,
count=
ers, variables, and conditional statements in a automatic way
(through evol=
ution) and besides, it is possible to perform a partial
derivate over the p=
arameter of the program (ANN Weights). That concept
is useful if you want t=
o perform a "gradient based method" to find a
solution (See LSTM articles o=
f Schmidhuber) as it is used in LSTM
original learning algorithm.

  I see =
your problem as Ken suggest, it is a "sequential problem" more
than a "Spat=
ial Problem". So:
-	The mapping happen through time when the net are able t=
o route the
card or piece value to the same "memory cell" independent of th=
e
position. It is a time ordering maper 
-	The roving eye has the property =
to get the useful events and values
and discard others, and map that's even=
ts and values in a useful way.
It exploits space if it is useful. LSTM help=
s to simplify the net as
it is a real memory and not a looping circuit keep=
ing a value
(...results of the experiment a have done).

  When you speak a=
bout "data buses" I image it trying to intercept a
groups of connections in=
 my brain=85no sense would be gotten. What I
know about brain in the visual=
 cortex is that the brain tries to
separate different features of an image =
from the retina. So if you try
to see one of this features Isolated nothing=
 would be gotten.
Therefore, I think it is more plausible that a "concept" =
is a "brain
state" of useful features in several memories of the nets, and
=
therefore I think it is not  "data" being transported through a "data
bus".=
 

  Example:
      In the "balancing pole control problem" with input exch=
ange (It
is the balancing pole problem but at the first of simulation we
ra=
ndomly exchange output control signals freezing that configuration
till the=
 end of that simulation), LSTM net is able to solve this problem.

  In thi=
s case, we have to modes of control, at the first of the
simulation, depend=
ing of the reaction of the system, the net see what
kinds of two configurat=
ions are set (feature perception). That value
is stored in a memory (probab=
ly some LSTM) and is kept through the
rest of the simulation. That variable=
 is a sort of context variable.
According to such context variable the syst=
em behaves in one of the
two modes. This is other case of symmetry where th=
rough an initial
perception the system remaps the output to use the same co=
ntrol part
of the net. 

Again, in this example, I see that it is an iterat=
ion between an
initial perception (remember the indifferent cards position =
in the 4
cards experiment), a context signal router (but not a formal bus) =
 and
a common net behaviour. 


Germ=E1n.


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ia=
n Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> At 23:59 19/01/2005, you wrote:
> 
> 
>=
 >--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> > > Re=
: egocentrism etc etc
> > >
> > > Hi,
> > >       This is an email that was=
 a long time coming and was far
closer to
> >the
> > > current topics on th=
e group when I started it but...
> > >
> > >       I have often wondered ho=
w it is that real neural networks
(e.g. me)
> >manage
> > > to exploit the =
"symmetry" in situations.
> > >
> > >       e.g. in the example of the egoc=
entric vs the
global-centric eye,
> >the
> > > reason the former has a easi=
er time of it is that it has some
> >exploitation
> > > of the symmetries o=
f the situation built into it.  That is the two
> >specific
> > > symmetrie=
s:
> > >
> > > 1) that the world retains the same nature as you translate t=
he
> >viewpoint around
> > > 2) that the world retains the same nature as y=
ou rotate the view
> > >
> > >       (one could call these "relativities" '=
cos they are just
like the
> > > assumptions underpinning relativity...)
> =
> >
> > >       The egocentric eye does not have full exploitation of them,=

> >however,
> > > because for any situation that requires considering the =
situation at
> >two
> > > points (or orientations) it is as badly off as th=
e global viewpoint.
> >  What
> > > this means is, if a piece of learning r=
equires the consideration of
> >the
> > > properties of more than one "posi=
tion" -- for example a position#1
> >where
> > > the prey could not see me,=
 and a position#2, where I could eat the
> >prey --
> > > then the eye can =
move to one of the positions, and get free
> >"relative"
> > > processing, =
but it has no way of performing any simultaneous
> >calculations
> > > at a=
 second position, except by evolving its own understanding of
> >the
> > > =
symmetry the hard way.
> > >
> > > --
> > >
> >
> >Just to be devil's advoc=
ate, are you sure it couldn't all just be done
> >by a roving eye with memo=
ry?  Maybe you never really do make
> >simultaneous computations for this t=
ype of thing.  Maybe it's all
> >sequential: look at the first perspective,=
 remember it, then transform
> >the view and look at the second.  In memory=
, perhaps both views are
> >stored in some kind of normalized reference fra=
me so they can be
> >thought of at once.
> 
> Hi,
> 
> Absolutely!  This is=
 a way in which it can be done, but the
discussion was 
> already long and =
complex without adding yet another consideration.
> 
> However, using memor=
y in this way does not really alter the case,
because 
> for memory to do t=
his, especially in conjunction with a general purpose 
> "symmetrical trans=
forms" system, it would still need to somehow pass
data 
> about between ge=
neral (memory, transformation) and specific
(prey-capture 
> or chess) modu=
les, again implying some sort of "data bus".
> 
> Not that I'm saying I bel=
ieve that real brains work that way, I'm just 
> holding up a set of phenom=
ena:
> 
>          - natural brains can learn a concept once and then apply=
 it
as a 
> module within multiple other learned behaviours
> 
> Asking how=
 they do it and then holding this idea of "data busses"
passing 
> informat=
ion around between remote parts of the network as a working 
> hypothesis. =
 Note however, that if you have a data bus then storing 
> something in a m=
emory module and pulling it back later is vary simple.
> 
> Note also, howe=
ver, that for a data bus to work _at_all_ there needs
to be 
> a consistent=
 format for the data in both the sending and receiving 
> modules.  Which i=
s the competing conventions problem with a vengeance.
> 
> However, it does=
 give us a different perspective of the definition of a 
> module.  e.g. in=
 a really nicely OO sort of way a module is 50%
defined by 
> the data form=
ats in its "interface"...
> 
>          Ian
